ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course was a great insight into development and evolution of feathers. For a student working on the evolution of birds from their dinosaur ancestors, it was definitively a great opportunity to expand my knowledge regarding the soft parts of these animals, generally not preserved in the fossil record, exception made for few sites in the World.
I learned a great deal about feather biology, including feather evolution, morphology, genetics, and coloration, by reading classic and recent papers from the literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is definitively strong and broad in terms of topics covered in class.I would have liked to have a more practical perspective, maybe adding a couple of labs to see ontogenetic and developmental series of feathers in extant birds. Overall, an amazing seminar

This course did a good job covering some of the major themes in feather biology. It also utilized and compared older and more recent literature, which provided a good historical context for discussions. The background information provided by the professor was also helpful, though at times too long. More group discussion would have been good.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is definitively a great seminar and very usell to understand the variety of these structures present in nature
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. But given it's highly specific nature, I would only recommend it to someone with a deep interest in birds and feathers.
